0'5GK3PIHEM'"Unleashing Twitter's Data: How to Access the Twitter API with JavaScript"'"

Connecting to the Twitter API through JavaScript is a powerful way to access Twitter data and build applications that integrate with Twitter. In this article
column2: we will guide you through the process of connecting to the Twitter API via JavaScript.
it's important to note that the Twitter API requires authentication for most endpoints. To authenticate
column3: you will need to create a Twitter developer account and generate API keys and access tokens. If you're looking for guidance on setting up a Twitter developer account and obtaining API keys
column4: you may find this article helpful
column5: which provides detailed instructions on how to create a Twitter developer account.

column1: Once you have your API keys and access tokens
column2: you can start building your JavaScript application to connect to the Twitter API.

column1: Step 1: Set up a Twitter API endpoint
The first step is to set up an endpoint that will allow your JavaScript application to access the Twitter API. We'll be using the fetch function to make HTTP requests to the Twitter API.

column2: you will need to build the API request using the fetch function. You will need to include your API keys and access tokens in the request headers.
'Bearer ' + 'YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN');
options)

column1: This code creates a new Headers object and adds the Authorization header to it with your access token. The fetch function is then used to make a GET request to the Twitter API
column2: passing in the headers and query parameters.
we're searching for tweets that contain the word ""javascript"".
you will need to handle the API response in your JavaScript application. In this example
column3: we're simply logging the response data to the console.

column1: You can modify this code to display the data on a webpage
column2: store it in a database
column3: or perform other actions based on your application's requirements.

column1: Connecting to the Twitter API via JavaScript is a great way to access Twitter data and build applications that integrate with Twitter. By following the steps outlined in this article
column2: you can start building your own Twitter-powered applications.

column1:
Remember to always handle Twitter data responsibly and in compliance with Twitter's terms of service and developer policies. Happy coding!

column1:
1'YQSFZBOFC'EventBus Mesh'"

I've been thinking about this topic a lot lately when bringing EventBridge's EventBus into some applications. On the current projects I'm working on with existing code
column2: I've said 100 times
column3: if EventBridge existed when I started them
column4: I wouldn't have so much SNS->SQS based code lying around. But such is life when working in evolving tech. Enter the EventBus Mesh

column1: I want to start off with this idea that in a Microservice architecture I like to have everything be as independent as possible. That means the following items are each owned by the boudnary itself
• A way to publish that only that boundary to use
• A way to subscribe that only that boundary can use

column2: I built a lot of software that looked like the below. And for clarity
column3: there is 100% nothing wrong with this approach

column1: • A single or multiple DynamoDB Tables under its control
• SQS for subscribing to other SNS Topics (only it can read from)
• SNS Topic for publishing messages/events out to the ecosystem. Only it could publish to that topic
With the advent of EventBridge Pipes and the ability of EventBridge Rules to trigger a Step Function (like this pattern EventBridge Step Function Rule)
column2: I felt the need to explore replacing SNS/SQS with EventBridge for new features and projects.
nothing wrong with any of the above but I wanted to gain some additional capabilities

column1: • Rules - they are more expressive and powerful than simple SNS message filtering. Filtering saves execution cycles which saves on cost and saves on waste
• Schema Discovery - really nice feature to have messages/events be expressed through Schema

column2: they are fantastic for filtering
column3: encriching and transforming. For more on Pipes

column2: I save on wasted execution
column3: remove points of failure and eliminate Lambdas and other code that could introduce errors that have to be tested. This old article by Jeff Barr which describes the famous Keynote that Jeff Bezos did where he talks about ""undifferentiated heavy lifting"" is example why I like pushing this kind of code up to the cloud

column1: I drew up this simple diagram to highlight how I see putting Buses together.
Some of the core pieces of this pattern are this
• Functions (Lambda or Step) interact with DynamoDB
• Service A Bus connects to Service B Bus
• Service A Bus connects to Functions in Service A
• EventBridge Pipes are used to connect to DynamoDB on Service A and then are registered onto Service A Bus

The really important thing to nail down are the ""boundaries"". It's important to make sure that what owns what is isolated to that boundary. The real glue is Bus -> Bus. It's like Pub/Sub (and it is) but instead of susbscribing an SQS Queue to an SNS Topic
column2: you subscribe Service B's Bus to Service A's bus. Additionally
column3: make sure to specify the Rules around the data that will connect those buses together.

column1: The big con for me is that Bus B when connected to Bus A knows about Bus A. But if Queue B nows about Topic A
column2: in my mind it's about the same thing. And in the case where this is all internal to one collection of products
column3: it doesn't bother me so hopefully it doesn't bother you was well.

column2: we are going to build two EventBuses and connect them together. Very similar to the diagram above.

column1:
2'GG6BRHQM6'Lightning Web Components: Custom Nested Components'"

Lightning Web Runtime
column2: or LWR for short was released back in Spring 21 (v51.0). Even before the release of LWR
column3: most developers dreamed of being able to build custom nested components. We could see that OOTB (Out Of The Box) components could use them (see Tabs component).

column1: Salesforce recently released the ability to build custom LWCs with child <slot/>'s
column2: to allow nesting of components. Nested LWCs allow you to compose multiple components together into a single component. The child components maintain their own life cycle and can communicate with each other through events
column3: making it easy to create flexible and dynamic apps.

column2: Aura based Communities are (sadly) not supported. So if you're currently using them it might be time to make the switch to LWR.
lets jump into the code and see the magic happen.

column1: We'll start by creating the HTML template to hold our <slot/>'s.
Now lets have a look at the JavaScript. The important part (or magic) here is the @slot definitions in the comment directly above the LWC export. Without these definitions
column2: the dynamic components will not work.

column1: The isAura check also ensures this component shows a warning in the experience builder when it is being used from within an Aura based community.
import { LightningElement } from 'lwc'
export default class NestedLWCs extends LightningElement {
return window['$A'] !== undefined && window['$A'] !== null

Make sure your .xml file is setup to be available in the experience builder. The key values are setting isExposed to true and including both lightningCommunity__Page and lightningCommunity__Default as targets.
Now lets open up the Experience Builder and see our custom LWC in action.
We can also nest components within other nested components. I am not aware of any limitation here. I was able to place up to 10 levels deep without any issues
column2: noting theses are very barebones test LWCs. More complex LWCs may start affecting performance.
nested LWCs provide a powerful and flexible way for developers to create custom components that can be composed of multiple other components
column3:
making it easier to build dynamic and reusable apps on the Experience Cloud platform.

3'551KZ7HZX'Why Rust has Such a Complex Syntax'"

Rust has a complex syntax because it is a systems programming language that aims to provide low-level control over computer hardware
column2: while also maintaining safety and performance. To achieve these goals
column3: Rust has a number of advanced features
column4: such as a powerful macro system

column1: The complex syntax of Rust is a result of these features
column2: which require a more nuanced and detailed syntax than simpler languages. For example
column3: Rust's ownership system and borrow checker are key features that make Rust memory safe and prevent common memory-related bugs such as null pointer dereferences and data races. However
column4: these features also require a more complex syntax to specify how ownership and borrowing work in different contexts.

column2: Rust's syntax is designed to be expressive and concise
column3: which can make it appear more complex at first glance. However
column4: once you become familiar with Rust's syntax and features
column5: it can actually make programming in Rust more efficient and easier to reason about.

column1: Here are some examples of complex Rust syntax:

Rust's ownership and borrowing system relies on lifetimes to ensure memory safety. Lifetimes are annotations that indicate the duration of a reference to a value. They are expressed using the 'a syntax
column2: where a is a variable name that represents the lifetime. Here's an example:

column1: fn longest<'a>(x: &'a str
column2: y: &'a str) -> &'a str {

column1: Rust's macro system allows for the creation of custom syntax extensions that can be used to generate code at compile time. Macros are defined using the macro_rules! syntax. Here's an example:
println!(""The value of x is: {}""
column2: $x);
the my_macro macro takes an expression $x and generates code that prints the value of $x using the println! macro.

the match_tuple function takes a tuple t and uses pattern matching to determine where the tuple lies on a coordinate plane. The match keyword is used to match each possible pattern of the tuple
column3: with each pattern consisting of a combination of values and placeholders. The format! macro is used to generate a string representation of the matching pattern.

column1:
7'P42N31O5K'How to Add Estimated Review Time and Context Labels to Pull Requests'"

The pull request (PR) review process
column2: if not set up well in your team
column3: can create a lot of bottlenecks in getting your code merged into the main branch and into production. By adding more context and information automatically to your PRs
column4: you save yourself and your team work.

column1: Take the scenario of fixing a typo in documentation. If theres a backlog of PRs that need attention
column2: such a PR may take two days or longer just to be approved. This is where continuous merge (CM) with gitStream comes in.

column1: gitStream is a tool that allows you to add context and automation to your PRs
column2: classifying PRs based on their complexity.

column1: This ensures that a review won't stay in the queue for long as it can be quickly assigned to the right person
column2: immediately approved or have the appropriate action identified easily.

column1: This hands-on article demonstrates how to add gitStream CM to your repository.

column2: youll learn:

column1: • How to Add the CM Feature to Your PRs
If youre keen to get all the benefits of gitStream and continuous merge right away
column2: all you need to do is follow these simple steps. If you want to understand how gitStream works
column3: how you can customize it and more options

column1: • Choose Install for free on gitStream's GitHub marketplace page
A Comprehensive Guide to gitStream & Continuous Merge
Filter functions and context variables are used to effect automated actions
column2: such as adding labels (add-label@v1)

column1: Everything is included in a .cm configuration file named gitstream.cm.
All instructions to gitStream CM are detailed in the docs found at docs.gitstream.cm. gitStream also uses GitHub Actions to do its work
column2: so youll need to add the gitstream.yml file to your GitHub Actions directory at .github/workflows/.

column1: The main components to fulfill gitStreams CM are:
• The filter functions: Code that tries to check and/or select certain data types from the input for checks during a PR creation.
• The context variables: The inputs fed to the filter functions.
Note: Some steps use Python only for demonstration purposes. Its not required knowledge.

column2: ensure you have the following:

column1: <li>Hands-on knowledge of Git and GitHub workings. You must know activities such as creating a repository
column2: PRs

column1: You can find and review the final project code here.
Step 1 - Set Up gitStream on Your Repo
Create an empty repo and give it a name
column2: then install gitStream to it from the marketplace.
you can either: 1) Clone the repository to your environment; or 2) Create a folder and point it to the repository. This tutorial uses the second option.

column2: create two directories

column1: Many organizations and teams may see microservices as the best approach to a determined problem. This post covers 5 basic concepts to think about when implementing this type of architecture. The idea is to revise some concepts that will help you question the need for this approach.
Microservices are services that attend a certain domain and are released independently. These services could then be exposed to other services through API's
column2: Service Brokers

column1: Many consider independent deployability the most important piece to microservices. Applying this concept is necessary to validate applications that are loosely coupled. To validate this one should be able to makes changes to a microservice without having to change other non-related services.

It is highly recommended that each microservice contains its own database. When we think of a microservice as a unique piece of software it should have independence in all levels and that includes the database. When one or more microservice share the same database one can easily fall into the assumption of shared deployment or accessing the same data between these services.
With a microservice approach each microservice needs to be independent and organized to effectively allow for independence. Design techniques like layered architecture
column2: clean architecture
column4: etc. These approaches may allow for teams to structure the code with independent contextualization efficiently.

column1: With the growth of business and processes within an organization the tendency is that the number of services will also grow. However the consumers of these microservices needs to be able to effectively communicate or call the microservice for the desired job. There are a couple of strategies to solve this issue. Having an API gateway is a strategy to expose
column2: version and evolve microservices effectively.

column1: This post contains only the tip of the iceberg when it come to microservices. To develop this type of solution more situations needs to be considered like the teams experience
column2: deployment automation

column1: The increase in complexity and team experience when creating microservices are many times why these projects tend to fail. It is common to have less experience or reduced teams working on software projects
column2: with the mindset of a microservice architecture.
planned
column4: but I always tend to ask myself why not microservices.

column1:
11'KSN3J115C'How to Empower Your Team with Test Automation'"

Test automation is a critical capability that makes the difference in delivering software with quality and speed
column2: letting the team adapt faster software changes to meet the quality requirements. But its implementation is hard.

column1: Test automation has become an essential tool for organizations looking to stay competitive and deliver high-quality products on time and on budget in the rapid pace of technological change and increasing complexity of software systems.

The integration of test automation activities in the software delivery pipeline requires the transversal collaboration of multiple actors not necessarily familiarized with quality or testing activities and thats why a leader needs to empower the team to succeed.

column2: pressured by accelerated competition
column3: have to lead fast transformations to capture opportunities before challengers do. This article shares how to make the difference when it comes to accelerating software delivery with test automation.

column1: Over 57 different test cases for e-commerce websites and application are covered to guarantee a flawless and secure purchasing experience for customers.
Share the value of test automation

Your team has to understand that test automation is not just a tool for quality assurance or testing teams. It is a valuable capability to develop for the entire software development process and for the business.
The value of test automation lies in its ability to improve the quality and speed of software delivery
column2: which in the end helps the company to develop better products and services for its customers more quickly and more efficiently.

column1: Software teams that try to accelerate without test automation face accumulating technical debt that sooner or later translate into painful issues like recurring bugs
column2: extra hours to fix problems
column3: or performing recurring manual tests that are of low interest and too slow.

column1: Your team has to understand the following benefits of test automation:
• Production efficiency by detecting and fixing issues earlier
The recommended way to share the value of test automation is to acculturate your team with external examples of successful usage of test automation for similar problems you are facing. That way
column2: people can start to consider test automation as a realistic solution for what they want to improve
column3: avoiding feeling forced to do so.

column2: your responsibility as a leader is to envision the path to follow
column3: share lights out of the tunnel
column4: and help them to visualize the future with better outcomes than the current situation leveraging test automation.

column1: Lead the way for the first steps
Having the team convinced about the value of test automation is the first step. Still
column2: much ambiguity will remain about which actions to follow
column4: and what to focus on as a priority.

column1: The responsibility of a leader is to navigate that initial fog
column2: deconstructing the complexity into clear outcomes the team can follow. The clarity of actions will enable the team to focus on the first actions to implement test automation.
you have to clarify:

column1: • Who is involved and should do what

The definition of this initial perimeter enables you to set the stage for an early-win team and share more broadly in the organization about the change. The advantages of a small team are to test and adapt new processes more rapidly with minimum effort.

The team will encounter roadblocks and issues in the first steps of implementation. Your role as a leader is to help them in problem-solving to demonstrate that the subject is essential and how you expect things to be solved.

column2: the tooling question will be a structuring one to address early on to set your team on the right track.

column1: Our Gaming Platform Test Case Templates tutorial offers a step-by-step guide for effective test scenarios. Improve your games quality and performance today.
Invest in the right tools and technologies
Adopting the right technology makes test automation more efficient
column2: effective
column3: and accessible for your team to set up and maintain in the long run. Once again
column4: your responsibility as a leader is to step back to improve the decision taken for your organization.

column1: Many tools compete in the test automation space to help teams deliver better software. Your value is to set clear priorities of what will be a game-changer for your organization
column2: and what should not be looked at all.

column1: The important part is to clarify the structuring requirements specific to your context:

column2: sharing and reporting?
which languages?

column1: • Can you combine multiple test techniques like Web & API?

Answering these questions will clarify the most important functions and requirements your organizations need to capture value from test automation. The next step is to translate the requirements into possible technology solutions.

column2: Test Execution
column3: and Test Reporting are the major vertical solutions needed to implement test automation. Specific narrowed tools exist for each vertical
column4: but there are also unified test automation platforms like LambdaTest that bundle the offer.

column1: The main capabilities to look at in your choice is the usability of the solution by different profiles to foster end-to-end collaboration in the organization. The availability of on-demand devices
column2: native reportings
column3: and intelligent features is also a strong factor of creating more value with test automation
column4: and of the capability of the tool to be innovative.

column1: Learning from the results of your automated tests enables you to replicate successes and avoid mistakes in the future
column2: and develop a continuous improvement culture that is essential to increase the maturity of software quality practices.

column1: One of the key benefits of test automation is to generate useful data that can be analyzed to identify patterns and trends. This data can be used to identify key areas of improvement and identify bottlenecks in processes to know where to focus your teams efforts.

column2: you can
column4: identify which tests are taking the longest to run
column6: and providing the most value. With more maturity
column7: you can even prioritize test execution based on their value to get faster feedback loops.

column1: But learning is not only about the tests and technology.
Performing retrospectives with your team enables you to discover other areas of improvements such as in processes
column2: skills
column4: providing you with the big picture necessary to solve structuring problems.

column1: That learning process will support the expansion of test automation practices in your organization much more easily. Leverage also internal influencers and people ready to act as key users to diffuse more efficiently what works best in your context.

column2: you can accelerate the deployment of test automation by providing on-demand training
column4: and ready-to-use templates. You then have to continuously encourage collaboration and communication to keep improving in the long run.

column1: You can also empower your team faster and save them valuable time by addressing key challenges of test automation right from the start.

column2: but common challenges will be faced when implementing test automation
column3: whatever the context. One essential responsibility of a leader is to address them early on to set the team in the best conditions to make a difference.

column1: Managing changes in organizations is about evolving in realistic transition stages that will bring enough value and manage the risks involved. Correctly size the challenges of each transition will sustain the teams momentum and motivation.
Heres common test automation challenges to address early on:
• Produce valuable outcomes by focusing on concrete problems where test automation can makes the difference and show its value to the organization
• Reduce initial cost and effort of implementation limiting scope
column2: tools and processes to the essential
column3: and using SaaS to limit capital expenditures

column1: • Availability of skilled and experienced profiles you can manage with internal mobility
column2: external expertise

column1: • Limit maintenance and updates efforts requiring to limit automation at first to increase its stability and ability to update them with software changes
• Clarity of leadership and coalition leading first
column2: and progressively defining a responsibility model to spread test automation responsibilities across teams

column1: Leaders have to balance the competing demands of different stakeholders and priorities to address these challenges. It requires proactivity and adaptability to effectively adapt the value proposition of test automation to each stakeholders interests.

Anticipating issues is the hard part of leading transversal changes in organizations like test automation. but will contribute to the most important goal of supporting the organization in remaining competitive todays digital competition landscape.
Empowering for Better and Faster Software
Test automation creates a differentiating advantage for organizations searching to continuously deliver Quality at Speed software. More than technology
column2: test automation favors an end-to-end collaboration on the delivery of better and faster software.

column1: Your responsibility as a leader is to develop a test automation capability by empowering your team to overcome the first obstacles and set the right foundations that will generate valuable outcomes for the organization
column2: to then be deployed more broadly with other teams.

column1: Theres no valuable transformation without challenges thats where a leader able to empower the team can unlock the potential of each team member to solve whatever problems emerged to progress towards the delivery of better and faster software.
